column13: Our Renewable Energy Procurement Strategy has been designed to drive our go-to-market approach to meeting this target. It is focused on long-term Power Purchase Agreements and Large-scale Generation Certificates, which are aligned with our Energy Management Policy and dependent on availability and cost considerations.
column20: Renewable energy. Procurement, Power Purchase Agreements

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization

column7: In 2023, energy reductions occurred in our fixed networks, corporate offices and retail footprint due to site consolidation and reduced locations. At the same time, the energy consumed by our mobile network increased as customers used more data, particularly on our 5G network.\t

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column13: Felix Mobile continues to operate on 100 per cent renewable electricity and is certified carbon neutral by the Australian Government's Climate Active initiative. It also continues to partner with One Tree Planted, where one new tree is planted monthly. Each Felix customer maintains an active subscription.
column20: Renewable electricity, Carbon neutral, Tree planting

Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: As owners and operators of telecommunications infrastructure, we recognise our potential impact on the environment. To address this, we have a range of robust processes and controls in place to manage environmental risk effectively across our operations.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity

column7: 1,476,453 total trees donated through One Tree Planted program

column13: The program's first stage, our pilot 'net-zero initiative', is focused on our emissions reduction targets and aims to Raise awareness with our suppliers by providing an overview of our emissions reduction targets. Understand the level of maturity across our supply chain regarding their emissions footprints and reduction strategies. Collaborate with key suppliers to set and achieve emissions reduction targets.
column20: Net-zero initiative, Supplier engagement, Emissions reduction targets

column13: Supporting our commitment to the Business Ambition for the 1.5ÃÂ°C campaign, the SBTi classified our targets as aligned with the 1.5ÃÂ°C trajectory. It is the trajectory to limit global temperature increases to 1.5 degrees Celsius, required to avoid the worst effects of climate change.\t
column20: SBTi validation, Trajectory, Climate change, Emission reduction

column13: Having set our greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets at the end of 2022, we were proud to become the first telco in Australia to have its net-zero target validated by the Science Based Target initiative in 2023. Our short-term and long-term targets were also validated and classified as in line with a 1.5ÃÂ°C trajectory to limit global warming to 1.5ÃÂ°C.
column20: SBTi validation, Trajectory, Climate change, Emission reduction

column13: Developing a strategy and implementation plan to support the achievement of science-based emissions reduction targets. Powering our Australian operations with 100 per cent renewable electricity by 2025.
column20: Emissions reduction strategy, Renewable electricity, Carbon neutrality

column13: In 2022, we mapped the carbon footprint of our operations and value chain for the first time, establishing our 2021 GHG emissions baseline, which we used to set our emissions reduction targets. TPG Telecom has completed a total carbon footprint assessment for the 2022 and 2023 years, allowing us to track trends in our data for the first time.
column20: Carbon footprint mapping, Emissions baseline, Trend tracking

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column7: We aim to be responsible for our products by minimising their environmental impact throughout their lifecycle. We continue to monitor and report our operational waste footprint in our Sustainability Data Pack. We aim to drive improvements across other parts of our value chain, working with our suppliers to reduce packaging and increase resource recoverability and with industry partners on e-waste management.

column13: Recognising the significance of e-waste in the telecommunications industry, we take responsibility for seriously reducing the amount of e-waste in our products. We continue to work with MobileMuster, the product stewardship program funded by the Australian mobile telecommunications industry, to increase the collection and recycling of end-user e-waste.\t
column20: E-waste reduction, Product stewardship, Recycling programs

column13: This year, we conducted communications campaigns to raise awareness and encourage uptake of the MobileMuster program. It included campaigns through Vodafone sales channels to enable customers to trade in or recycle their devices, a Today Show segment filmed at one of our retail stores, and internal messaging for retail employees to promote device recycling during new promotions.
column20: Awareness campaigns, Recycling initiatives, Circular economy

column13: Circularity and waste recovery will also be a defined aspect of our Supplier Engagement Program, where we collaborate with key suppliers on waste and e-waste reduction. We have communicated this to suppliers through our net-zero survey and a recent presentation to our technology suppliers.
column20: Supplier engagement, Waste reduction, E-waste management

column13: Our Consumer Digital team helped Clean Up Australia to understand the business case and potential value of a purpose-built app and how it could support its mission through growing engagement from the Australian public.
column20: Digital solutions, Engagement platforms, Environmental conservation

column7: Corporate office waste directed to disposal: 76%

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
column13: We also undertook a review better to understand our risks and impacts on nature and biodiversity. We learned that our supply chain's most considerable nature-related impacts and dependencies are upstream. While we effectively manage the environmental impact of our operations, opportunities exist to develop a more coordinated approach to nature across our value chain, including working with suppliers to understand better and manage the nature and biodiversity risks they face.
column20: Nature and biodiversity review, Supply chain impact, Collaboration

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: In 2023, we developed a net-zero survey issued to our top 150 suppliers to raise awareness of our commitments and gather information on their maturity regarding emissions and reduction targets. Responses will guide engagement efforts with critical suppliers to drive the setting and achievement of supplier emission reduction targets.
column20: Supplier engagement, Emissions reduction targets, Collaboration, Net-zero survey
